14.title: Your Character

141.content:
My name is Doria Moana. I was twelve, going on thirteen, when it all started. I was, or at least I thought I was, an ordinary girl. A fisherman's daughter in a small fishing town on the shores of Hawaii. That all changed when I got my first period.

Fortunately, I was home at the time, feeling rather ill. Dad seemed rather sad when I told him, and I almost went to school despite how bad I felt, but he insisted I stay in bed. I had read up on a woman's menstrual cycles, and thought I was prepared for my first. Only when I found gold-colored scales, like on a goldfish, forming upon my skin, I screamed at the top of my lungs.

Dad was quick to enter my room, seemingly ready for anything. Upon seeing the scales on my arm, however, his eyes teared up, and he sat down next to me. "I was hoping this wouldn't start for a while." Sadly, he said. "It looks like you're going to meet your mother sooner than planned."

"Dad, you're scaring me." Tearing up, I said. "What is happening to me?"

"You wouldn't believe me if I told you." sighing, Dad said.

"Try me." Insistent, I said. "I'm the one with fish scales growing on me."

Dad chuckled. "Well, Doria,... you are becoming a mermaid."

"A... what?" Taken aback, I demanded.

Dad nodded. "Those old sailor stories have more truth to them than you might think." Calmly, he said. "There was a terrible storm a little over fifteen years ago. It was my first commanding role, on an ocean research vessel called The Searcher."

"I remember you told me that story." Teary eyed, I said. "You saved everyone on board, nearly drowning in the process."

"That was when I first met your mother." To my surprise, Dad said. "Her name was Ariana, a direct descendant of the very first mermaid."

If they could, my eyes would have grown wider. "What happened?"

"When in a storm out at sea, waves are not measured in inches or feet, they are measured in increments of fear." Serious, Dad said. "I ordered the entire crew below decks, and took the controls alone."

As Dad told his story, I could picture the scene...

The waves were towering, and they crashed down with unforgiving force. Dad stood out in the elements, the pilot house all but destroyed by the storm. He struggled with the wheel, his body tied down to the deck with ropes, as he steered for the safety of a sheltered cove. He was using the occasional flashes of lightning to see his way. Dad screamed at the storm, shaking a single fist at the threatening clouds, as if to curse it for upsetting the calm sea.

A terrifying wave crashed against the side of the vessel, nearly capsizing it, but Dad turned the vessel into the wave and used it to propel his ship closer to the cove. Lightning flashed across the sky, illuminating the jagged rocks, and Dad spun the wheel, just in time to avoid running aground in the powerful storm. Just as the ship kissed the opening of the cove, a massive wave struck the ship, breaking the ropes and hurling Dad into the sea...

"I thought, that was it... I was dead." softly, Dad said. "Only a soft hand touched mine, and I turned to see the most beautiful woman I had even laid eyes upon."

"Ariana." Whispering, I said. I was hanging on every word, picturing every detail of Dad's tale.

Dad nodded. "She pulled me with such speed, it dislocated my shoulder." Quietly, he said. "I screamed as I reached the surface, and she let me go, swimming off back into the sea as quickly as she had come."

"You met her again, though." Hopeful, I said. "Come on, Dad, this is more than you had ever told me!"

Dad chuckled. "The question is, are you ready to hear it, or do you think I'm still telling tall tales of the sea?"

I sighed, frustrated. "Dad, you're terrible." Pouting, I said. "Don't tease me right now."
141.title: Strange tales of the sea.

choices: I hear a call from the water.
1411.content:
Dad smiled. "I did meet her again, a year after." Calmly, he said. "Only I was the one to save her this time."

"What happened?" Whispering, I asked.

"First, I was not exaggerating when I told you I was a champion brawler." With a hint of pride, Dad said. "I can hold my own in any fight, even today, at my age."

Again, as Dad told his story, I could see the events unfold...

Dad was heading back to his ship, the Searcher, when he heard a woman crying for help. It wasn't too far away, so he ran to investigate. He found the woman he had met in the ocean on the beach, cornered by four muscular blurry men. Dad could not believe his eyes, it was a beached mermaid. They men surrounding her were grinning among themselves, talking about how much money a real mermaid would bring them. Dad had a strong sense of right and wrong, and what he was seeing was all wrong. He ran up to the scene and challenged the men, who turned their attention to him. The woman looked up at Dad with hope in her eyes, which was all he needed to commit.

The first man took a swing, but he was too slow for Dad's reflexes, and was rewarded with a high roundhouse kick to the jaw, sending him off his feet. The second and third man charged Dad, each with a hunting knife in hand. Dad caught the hand of one and kicked the other in the groin. This gave Dad all the time he needed to head butt the one he was holding, before sending him to the sand with a powerful uppercut. The fourth man produced a gun, but Dad had already taken the knife from the second man and threw it into the fourth man's hand, forcing him to drop it. At this point, it was now only two against one. Dad took down the one closest to him with a judo chop, then kicked up a rock from the sand and threw it into the head of the last man, just as he had picked up his gun...

"With all four men out cold, I took the woman into my arms, and carried her back into the water." Calmly, dad said. "Only she surprised me."

I was again hanging onto every word. "What did she do?"

"Her tail separated into two tails, then became a pair of silky legs." Smiling, Dad said. "She then rolled out of my arms and kissed me." He sighed, tears falling. "That was when she told me her name, Ariana."

Dad cursed under his breath, pulling a tissue from a box on my nightstand to dab at his eyes. I couldn't help tearing up as well. "You miss her, don't you?"

"Every time I come back from the sea." Sadly, Dad replied. "If it were not for you, life on land would be unbearable."

With that said, Dad walked out of my room, hiding the fact he was crying. I had a sad feeling he felt he was about to lose me.

********** **********


I had to get out of the house, to think, to give both Dad and me some space. He had always told me that he and Mom were never too far away, and that I would meet her when the time was right. Still, his story about how he met my mom seemed to really tear at his heartstrings. I had never seen him cry in my life, it made me want to cry with him. I instead began to cry as I walked out on my own down the sidewalk, trying to digest it all.

"There is still more of the story to tell... " Sadly, I muttered. "How did he move from being an oceanographer to a fisherman? What happened to the Searcher, and why has he never told this story before today? I always knew him owning Heart of Doria."

A ping of pain in my arm caused me to pause and look. Upon seeing what caused the pain, the tears came faster. It was another small patch of scales... just like I had seen on a goldfish. It shimmered in the light and sent shivers down my spine with the slightest touch. Dad's story was real. The tears came faster, I had never felt more lost, or confused, or frightened in my life. I was in a bit of a fog when I bumped into Cordelia and Adrian.

"Honey, what's wrong?" Seeing my tears, Cordelia demanded. "Why are you crying?"

Adrian frowned, his expression showing his protective side. "What's his name?" Gruffly, he demanded. "We'll break his kneecaps."

A hiccup-like laugh escaped my lips. Adrian could certainly be a brat at times, as most brothers were, but I never met anyone more caring or protective as he. "I'm going through more changes than most girls deal with." Softly, I replied. "Dad filled me in on some of it."

Adrian winced. "He gave you 'The Talk'?"

Now I really laughed. "No,... he told me about how he met my mother."

Cordelia sighed, a sad look on her face. "It's that time, isn't it?" Softly, she asked.
1411.title: Dad tells me more.

14111.content:
"What time?" Curious, Adrian asked.

Cordelia gave Adrian a sweet smile. "Time for your nap..."

She took a hold of Adrian's shoulder as he responded, "My wha..." He was out cold before he could finish.

Cordelia sighed, then turned to me. To say I was surprised would have been an understatement.

"What did you do to him?"

"Relax, he's just asleep for a while." Calmly, Cordelia said. "He's too young to know or even grasp what I am about to tell you."

"You know about this.. . ?" Taken aback, I asked.

Cordelia nodded. "You see, Doria,... I'm a mermaid too." Softly, she replied. "It was my job to protect you, and Jonas, your father, until you were ready to go to the sea."

"You can live on land and sea?" Surprised, I asked. "Then why... ?"

Coral gave a sad smile. "Then why is your father so sad? It is because only adult mermaids can move from the sea to the land and back. He will not see you for a few years, once your transformation is complete."

I rubbed my arm, uncomfortable. "Is Adrian a merman?"

Cordelia nodded. "He still has a few years before he will be joining us." softly, she said. "Still, this is why your father is so sad right now."

"First, mermaids and mermen alike can't have sex or reproduce in their oceanic forms, due to having no genitals." Serious, Cordelia explained. "Only while in human form can they mate to carry on the supernatural species." She sighed. "It is only during the night of a full moon that mermaids ovulate."

"Once a month... " sighing, I said. "I have a feeling this is The Talk for mermaids."

Cordelia nodded. "In mermaids, reproduction is much like that of dolphins." Calmly, she said. "Mermaid babies are born live in the ocean, near the surface."

"So they are all raised on land?" Curious, I asked.

"This is why you never hear sailors telling stories of child mermaids." Serious, Cordelia said. "It is also why there is a high rate of missing teenagers in this part of the world."

"Because it's a mermaid community." surprised, I said.

Cordelia smiled. "There are, of course, lots of normal humans here, too." Softly, she said. "Just don't be too surprised if you meet an acquaintance or two when you go to live in the ocean with your mother."

I sighed, hearing that. "What can I expect down there?" Worried, I asked.

"Well, you will be escorted to where we live, but I won't ruin it by describing it to you." Bemused, Cordelia replied. "As for what to expect, you will find many mermen interested in getting to know you better."

"Why?" Wincing, I asked.

Then I saw Cordelia smile, and cringed. "Ew... "

Cordelia laughed. "They are not all, as they say on the surface, wolves." Smiling, she said. "Besides, it's the girls who pick the boys, not the other way around, like here."

"That's unusual." Curious, I said.

"Not if you take into account the fact that mermen are shorter and less muscular than the mermaids." Smiling, Cordelia said. "Or have you not noticed that Adrian is shorter than most boys his age?"

I was about to ask more, but Adrian moaned and pulled himself off of the floor. "What- what happened... ?" Groggy, he demanded.

"You tripped." Simply, Cordelia replied. "I was about to worry, as you hit your head."

"You need to be more careful, bro." Catching on, I added.

Adrian shrugged. "What were we talking about?"

Cordelia and I grinned.

******************************


The following day, I found more golden scales on my sides and parts of my chest, as well as on parts of my leg. After hearing Cordelia's story, I didn't know how I felt. On one hand, I did want to meet my mother. But, on the other, I didn’t want to hurt Dad by leaving him behind. It brought me to tears all over again, and I began to cry out my frustrations in my room. Hearing me, Dad knocked on my door. "Honey... are you okay... ?"

"I don't want to leave you, Daddy... " Crying, I replied. "Cordelia gave me The Talk for mermaids, and a little of what I can expect."

"You won't be leaving me forever, sweetheart." Hugging me, Dad said. "Also, think of how long your mother had to wait after you were born to see you."

I could not argue with that, but I was still worried. "Can't you go with me... ?"

Dad shook his head. "Not until Adrian has his changes." Softly, he said. "What kind of father would I be if I left him an orphan, just to be with you and your mother a little early?"

"So it won't really be goodbye." Smiling slightly, I said.

"Of course not." Cooing to me, Dad said. "Only one of us had to remain on land to care for you, and then Adrian."

I winced. "Did you and Cordelia... "

Dad chuckled. "As far as the landlubbers are concerned, yes." Calmly, he replied. "Only in mermaid society, I am considered a stepfather, due to agreeing to being a father figure for a mermaid's child."

"What... ?" confused, I asked.

"Cordelia's mate died, Doria." Sadly, Dad explained. "I agreed to raise Adrian as my own, and she agreed to look after you, until it was time to return to the sea, and take Adrian and me with her when it becomes his turn."

"I didn't know that." Surprised, I said.

"There are a lot of things you don't know." smiling, Dad said. he chuckled. "Mainly because you didn't need to know, and you wouldn't likely believe it."

"What happened to The Searcher you said you had captained?" Curious, I asked.

"The funding dried up, and I had to find another way to make a living." Shrugging, Dad replied. "Knowing my way around the ocean and the habits of the local fish, I became a fisherman, recommissioning my ship to The Heart of Doria." He smiled. "That was when I met Cordelia."

"Wait... what happened to Mom during that time?!" Worried, I demanded.

Dad again smiled. "Which do you want to hear first, what happened to your mom, or how I met Cordelia?"

I pouted. "You're terrible, Daddy... "

Dad shrugged. "I'd be happy to tell you both tales, but only one at a time." Calmly, he said. "It's not my fault you find it a difficult decision."

I sighed, then...

15.content:
Above the waist, merfolk are much like humans. The differences are the gill slits on the neck, and slight webbing on the fingers.

About navel level, the skin begins to develop a coating of fish scales. The lower body is a fishlike tail, about twice the length of a human lower body.

Merfolk pregnancies have the same duration as their human counterparts, and their children are born live. After nursing at the mother's breast, the merbaby will swim close to the mother until she stops lactating, generally about the time the child begins teething.

Merfolk can assume human form when out of water. They also have the ability to alter sex, so that trans merfolk may live as their true selves.

Merfolk live an average of 150 years.

Merfolk technology is far advanced beyond what is available on the surface, so much so that it is indistinguishable from magic.
